<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 376, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 128, 91]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 103, 625, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1}\right)\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 566, 170, 583]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 599, 324, 616]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 598, 561, 636]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 650, 252, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 650, 530, 667]]<|/det|>
\(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 682, 153, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 680, 522, 700]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 723, 341, 741]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 536, 750]]<|/det|>
\[f_{\mathrm{o}} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}V}{V\pm V_{\mathrm{s}}}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 763, 208, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 763, 532, 780]]<|/det|>
\(I = A n v q\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 794, 230, 811]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 794, 588, 813]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 828, 240, 846]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 821, 599, 856]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 79, 539, 98]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential \(\phi = - \frac{GM}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 121, 554, 144]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{P}} = - \frac{GMm}{r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 165, 571, 190]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas \(p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 201, 539, 220]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion \(a = - \omega^2 x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 233, 571, 252]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m. \(v = v_0 \cos \omega t\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 250, 615, 275]]<|/det|>
\[v = \pm \omega \sqrt{(x_0^2 - x^2)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 291, 544, 312]]<|/det|>
electric potential \(V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 336, 544, 364]]<|/det|>
electrical potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{P}} = \frac{Qq}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 383, 601, 413]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series \(\frac{1}{C} = \frac{1}{C_1} + \frac{1}{C_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 426, 593, 446]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel \(C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 466, 556, 486]]<|/det|>
discharge of a capacitor \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 508, 524, 536]]<|/det|>
Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{nq}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 549, 561, 567]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage \(x = x_0 \sin \omega t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 580, 539, 598]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 612, 544, 641]]<|/det|>
decay constant \(\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 664, 576, 702]]<|/det|>
intensity reflection coefficient \(\frac{I_{\mathrm{R}}}{I_0} = \frac{(Z_1 - Z_2)^2}{(Z_1 + Z_2)^2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 718, 556, 737]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann law \(L = 4\pi \sigma r^2 T^4\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 758, 556, 782]]<|/det|>
Doppler redshift \(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} \approx \frac{\Delta f}{f} \approx \frac{v}{c}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 186, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 72, 517, 89]]<|/det|>
Define gravitational potential at a point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 101, 917, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 140, 917, 158]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 194, 181, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 194, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Starting from the equation for the gravitational potential due to a point mass, show that the gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of a point mass \(m\) at a distance \(r\) from another point mass \(M\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 250, 554, 279]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{p}} = -\frac{GMm}{r}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 500, 306]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 146, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the path of a comet of mass \(2.20 \times 10^{14} \text{kg}\) as it passes around a star of mass \(1.99 \times 10^{30} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 533, 845, 765]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 782, 591, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 813, 920, 846]]<|/det|>
At point X, the comet is \(8.44 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\) from the centre of the star and is moving at a speed of \(34.1 \text{km s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 860, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
At point Y, the comet passes its point of closest approach to the star. At this point, the comet is a distance of \(6.38 \times 10^{10} \text{m}\) from the centre of the star.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 816, 88]]<|/det|>
Both the comet and the star can be considered as point masses at their centres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 181, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the change in the gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the comet as it moves from position X to position Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 335, 920, 353]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}} =\) .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 181, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 920, 398]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether the change in gravitational potential energy in **(b)**(i) is an increase or a decrease.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 448, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 475, 180, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 880, 494]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(b)**(i) to determine the speed, in \(\text{km s}^{- 1}\), of the comet at point Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 707, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. \(\text{km s}^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 146, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 920, 786]]<|/det|>
A second comet passes point X with the same speed as the comet in **(b)** and travelling in the same direction. This comet is gradually losing mass. The mass of this comet when it passes point X is the same as the mass of the comet in **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 800, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
Suggest, with a reason, how the path of the second comet compares with the path shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 900, 920, 918]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 332, 90]]<|/det|>
State Coulomb's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 193, 141, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 193, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
Positronium is a system in which an electron and a positron orbit, with the same period, around their common centre of mass, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[213, 237, 779, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 457, 591, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 635, 507]]<|/det|>
The radius \(r\) of the orbit of both particles is \(1.59 \times 10^{-10} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 181, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
Explain how the electric force between the electron and the positron causes the path of the moving particles to be circular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 658, 178, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 655, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
Show that the magnitude of the electric force between the electron and the positron is \(2.28 \times 10^{-9} \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 907, 920, 925]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Use the information in **(b)**(ii) to determine the period of the circular orbit of the two particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>period = .................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 146, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
Positronium is highly unstable, and after a very short period of time it becomes gamma radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 396, 841, 415]]<|/det|>
Describe how gamma radiation is formed from the two particles in positronium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 181, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 551, 720, 570]]<|/det|>
State **one** medical application of the process described in **(c)**(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 581, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 504, 89]]<|/det|>
Define specific latent heat of vaporisation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 144, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water at atmospheric pressure of \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{ Pa}\) is \(2.3 \times 10^{6} \text{ J kg}^{-1}\) . A mass of \(0.37 \text{ kg}\) of liquid water at \(100^{\circ} \text{C}\) is provided with the thermal energy needed to vaporise all of the water at atmospheric pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 630, 275]]<|/det|>
Calculate the thermal energy \(q\) supplied to the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>q = .................................................... J [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 412, 181, 430]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
The mass of \(1.0 \text{ mol}\) of water is \(18 \text{ g}\). Assume that water vapour can be considered to behave as an ideal gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 458, 682, 477]]<|/det|>
Show that the volume of water vapour produced is \(0.64 \text{ m}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 630, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 660, 180, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 660, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
Assume that the initial volume of the liquid water is negligible compared with the volume of water vapour produced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 705, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the work done by the water in expanding against the atmosphere when it vaporises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 892, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in **(b)**(i) and **(b)**(iii) to determine the increase in internal energy of the water when it vaporises at \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Explain your reasoning.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 259, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
increase in internal energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 146, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
Use the first law of thermodynamics to suggest, with a reason, how the specific latent heat of vaporisation of water at a pressure greater than atmospheric pressure compares with its value at atmospheric pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 415, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 445, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 443, 89]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by resonance.

<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 154, 917, 171]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 146, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows a heavy pendulum and a light pendulum, both suspended from the same piece of string. This string is secured at each end to fixed points.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 241, 740, 438]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 456, 532, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 573, 504]]<|/det|>
Both pendulums have the same natural frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
The heavy pendulum is set oscillating perpendicular to the plane of the diagram. As it oscillates, it causes the light pendulum to oscillate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the displacements of the two pendulums for three oscillations.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[241, 597, 895, 870]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 892, 532, 910]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 767, 89]]<|/det|>
The variation with \(t\) of the displacement \(x\) of the light pendulum is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 102, 571, 120]]<|/det|>
\[x = 0.25\sin 5.0\pi t\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 527, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(x\) is in centimetres and \(t\) is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 183, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 532, 183]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T\) of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 317, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.2, label both of the axes with the correct scales. Use the space below for any additional working that you need.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 516, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 547, 180, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 547, 920, 580]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the phase difference \(\phi\) between the oscillations of the light and heavy pendulums. Give a unit with your answer.
